content.formatted_body:
All I know is, if you try to reuse it in Rust, it will be rejected by the compiler ðŸ˜‚

fn main() {
   let a = (1..5).into_iter();
   //   for i in &a {} NOT WORK
   for i in a {}
   for i in a {} // Error: Use moved value a
}

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body:
All I know is, if you try to reuse it in Rust, it will be rejected by the compiler ðŸ˜‚

   //   for i in &a {} NOT WORK

content.body: In general, iterators arenâ€™t reusable, with very few exceptions (notably, builtins like array) - i just donâ€™t think people are going to consistently have the intuition that they will be.

For those who will be in SF for TC39 in 12 days time, @sffc has organized a Community event on the Wednesday 20th evening at 17:30.

  https://github.com/tc39/Reflector/issues/437#issuecomment-1177199594

Please let Shane know if you would like to give a presentation or participate in the panel.

content.formatted_body:
In reply to @jackworks:matrix.org

All I know is, if you try to reuse it in Rust, it will be rejected by the compiler ðŸ˜‚

fn main() {
   let a = (1..5).into_iter();
   //   for i in &a {} NOT WORK
   for i in a {}
   for i in a {} // Error: Use moved value a
}

but you can do:

fn main() {
  let a = 1..5;
  for i in a {} // implicitly calls into_iter()
  for i in a {} // implicitly calls into_iter()
}

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body:
In reply to @jackworks:matrix.org

All I know is, if you try to reuse it in Rust, it will be rejected by the compiler ðŸ˜‚

fn main() {
   let a = (1..5).into_iter();
   //   for i in &a {} NOT WORK
   for i in a {}
   for i in a {} // Error: Use moved value a
}

but you can do:

fn main() {
  let a = 1..5;
  for i in a {} // implicitly calls into_iter()
  for i in a {} // implicitly calls into_iter()
}
